causes: The Qing Dynasty sought to secure its western borders and eliminate the threat posed by the Dzungar Khanate.
The Dzungar Mongols had resisted Qing control and engaged in multiple conflicts with Qing forces.
Emperor Qianlong aimed to integrate the western frontier into the empire and establish direct Qing rule over Xinjiang.
The Dzungars had launched raids into Qing territory, provoking military retaliation.
events_leading_up_to_war: The Qing had previously fought the Dzungars in earlier conflicts but had not fully subdued them.
Dzungar ruler Amursana rebelled against Qing authority, prompting a large-scale military campaign.
The Qing mobilized a vast army, including Han Chinese, Manchu Bannermen, and Mongol auxiliaries, to crush the Dzungars.

result.territorial_changes: Xinjiang was fully incorporated into the Qing Empire, with Qing rule extending over the Tarim Basin.

allies: Some Central Asian factions opposed to Qing rule

Dzungar_Khanate: Khoja Brothers (Burhan al-Din and Khwaja Jihan)

Qing_Dynasty.weapons: Firearms, cannons, cavalry, traditional Qing military formations

Dzungar_Khanate.weapons: Mongol cavalry, bows, spears, limited firearms

Dzungar_Khanate.captured: Tens of thousands executed or deported

major_battles.name: Battle of Ili
major_battles.description: A decisive Qing victory that led to the collapse of Dzungar resistance in northern Xinjiang.

major_battles.name: Siege of Kashgar
major_battles.description: Qing forces besieged and captured the key city of Kashgar, ending major resistance in southern Xinjiang.
major_battles.outcome: Qing occupation of Kashgar and full consolidation of Xinjiang.

texts.name: Qing Imperial Edicts
texts.details: Official documents detailing Emperor Qianlong’s orders for the campaign.

texts.name: Uyghur Chronicles
texts.details: Records describing the impact of the Qing conquest on the Uyghur population.

archaeological_evidence.description: Qing weapons, banners, and fortifications discovered in Xinjiang.
Destroyed Dzungar settlements found across the region, indicating large-scale devastation.

political: Xinjiang was fully integrated into the Qing Empire, with direct administration from Beijing.
Dzungar Mongols were largely exterminated or assimilated, ending their dominance in the region.
The Qing established a system of military garrisons to maintain control over Xinjiang.
long_term_effects: The demographic landscape of Xinjiang was permanently altered, with a dramatic decline in the Dzungar population.
Uyghur Muslim leaders were placed under Qing administration, leading to long-term tensions in the region.
Xinjiang became a crucial frontier for Qing interactions with Central Asia and Russia.

military: Showcased Qing military superiority in large-scale campaigns against nomadic powers.
Used a combination of direct military conquest and political manipulation to subjugate Xinjiang.
political: Marked the beginning of Qing dominance over Central Asia, shaping China’s western frontier.
Established policies that would influence later Chinese governance of Xinjiang.
cultural: Led to increased Chinese presence in Xinjiang, influencing its political and cultural development.
Qing policies reshaped the ethnic composition of the region, leading to future conflicts.
